title: Costa Group co-founder laments self-inflicted wounds
text:
Mr Costa, who holds a stake of less than 5 per cent in Costa Group, said he was unlikely to take up his share of entitlements in the raising. "I just want to see things settle down a bit,'' he said.

Costa Group on Monday announced a hefty profit downgrade, its fourth of the year, and an underwritten $176 million one-for-four entitlement issue at a steep discount of $2.20 per share. Costa Group is scheduled to come out of an extended trading halt on Wednesday. It last traded at $3.46.

Shares not taken up by institutions under their entitlements were due to be sold overnight in a shortfall bookbuild, scheduled to close at 8am on Wednesday.

Mr Costa said he was annoyed at the destruction in value of his own holding, but people needed to understand it was a cyclical industry which would eventually improve. "It's annoyed me, but it doesn't worry me.''

The value of the mushroom market in Australia had grown by almost 5 per cent in 2018, but has fallen around 2.5 per cent this year.

Costa Group chief executive Harry Debney said on Tuesday the company would only restore its credibility with investors by showing it could deliver consistent growth. "It's got to be demonstrated performance.''

He blamed a poorly timed marketing campaign promoting mushrooms early in 2019 for some of the issues in the segment.

The downturn in the mushroom sector hadn't been factored in. "It caught everyone by surprise.''

Advertisement

Mr Debney also described a dispute with Vitalharvest Freehold Trust, the ASX-listed landowner of large berry and citrus operations which Costa Group leases in NSW, Tasmania and South Australia, as ''noise'' which would be resolved.

He said Costa Group was furnishing information to Vitalharvest as required under the law.

Vitalharvest told the ASX on Tuesday that for the nine months to September the variable rent component for citrus crops leased to Costa was down 33 per cent compared with the previous three-year average.

Total variable rent was down 52 per cent on the prior three-year average.

Vitalharvest managing director Liam Lenaghan said it was ''disappointing the previously communicated favourable citrus harvest outlook hasn't materialised and the berry category has deteriorated''.

Costa leases 399 hectares of berry-producing land in NSW and Tasmania and 1942 hectares of citrus land in South Australia's Riverland district from Vitalharvest.

Other members of the Costa family also hold shares in Costa Group.

Citi analyst Craig Woolford cut his 12-month target price for Costa Group to $2.90, from $4.20 previously.

He labelled the balance sheet repair via the capital raising as ''costly'' and said while the company was suggesting prices of avocadoes, blueberries and mushrooms would improve in 2020, he believed the recovery would only be modest.

"Blueberry prices remain weak with industry production very high,'' he said.

Advertisement

The Costa family remain shareholders in the Costa Group, which they floated in 2015, after it was founded by Frank and Adrian Costa in 1959.

Frank Costa announced his retirement from the Costa board in July.
description: The co-founder of Costa Group has baulked at injecting more funds into the company.
